comment.author: 54017078@N00
comment._content:
Ormulv (snakewolf), now there's a name! So cool.

[Note: I think the image is flipped horizontally; the handwriting is backwards.]

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content:
grytlappar: Guess it could be confusing with the handwriting... Actually, someone less considerate has written with ink on the emulsion side of the glass plate negative. When scanning the negative correctly, the handwriting is then shown backwards as you have noticed. The text says: "Skederids sn. Uppland" ("Skederid parish, Uppland".) 

It's quite common to find some kind of writing on the old glass plate negatives. A kind of documentation of how photography was ranked in the archives way back in time = not always so high... 

/Anna B.

comment.author: 53191571@N04
comment._content: Pretty cool rune stone. By the way, you've got "greece" in the tags and this photo appears in irrelevant searches.

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content:
Reinvo: Glad you appreciate the rune stone. :) In the text below the photo you can see why someone added the tag greece: The runes were carved in memory of three men, two of them who died in Greece. So, there is a clear connection.
/Anna B.

comment.author: 7634692@N03
comment._content: Any date estimate for the inscription / rune stone ?

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content:
focalpointx: Rune stones like this one, with a simple runic inscription without ornaments, are usually dated to the beginning of the 11th century.  
/Anna B.
